text: everybody today I want to give you an
update on the expanding operator
ecosystem the operator community kind of
birthed out of this idea that you know
running stateless applications is pretty
easy to do on Cube and we got the staple
applications and then really quickly we
got to these advanced distributed
systems running on kubernetes and this
is really great but there aren't
primitives built in to kubernetes to
handle these types of applications if
you want to do data rebalancing or
seamless upgrades and so that's where an
operator enters the picture and
operators run these complex applications
on your behalf and the way that they
work is you take the experts in an
application how its installed how its
failed over how its upgraded and they
take that expertise and embed it into
the operator such that you take those
best practices and your customizations
of the application which might be
different in staging or production and
then translate those into kubernetes
objects that run on the cluster this is
really really powerful because you're
using kubernetes primitives in the
toolkit that you already get thanks to
all the hard work upstream so you're not
reinventing that and you're focusing on
your application and because you're
focusing on kubernetes you get something
that is truly hybrid you can take this
operator and run the application on any
kubernetes cluster out there move it
around as you would like the operator
framework is a set of tools that can
help you build these operators test them
and deploy them in production it's
really useful to look at an example of
these to really drive at home so let's
just say that we want to run Postgres
and we've got a number of options for
this we can run Postgres in a container
on our laptop that's really easy we
could also go pull off a cloud database
and get a bunch of nice features with
that or we could use the crunchy data
operator that runs Postgres for us and
as you can see the crunchy data operator
gives you that same cloud like
experience but we have a few special
extra superpowers one being that we can
run this locally I can run a full stack
on my laptop on a plane to do some
development or it's open source so you
can fully introspect what's going on
this is especially helpful when you want
to go look at the interactions between
some of the components go debug some of
the pods if you're running into an issue
and this is really really really
powerful and so what this gives you is
this extreme transparency into what's go
on so here we're looking at some
screenshots of a Kafka cluster and you
can see some of the environment
variables that were setting here you can
see different versions of the components
and then we can get streaming logs
because this is just running on our
cluster we've got full control over what
we can see and this is really nice for
you to see exactly what's going on under
the hood so I went and did some digging
and these tweets came across my timeline
and these are some folks that are
actually finding bugs in public cloud
services and what's interesting about
this the gentleman on the Left
spent 3 entire weeks debugging an
application I thought it was his bug and
actually turns out it's a bug in this
cloud database and so he's wasted three
weeks it's really great that the bug was
fixed in this case but you know we could
save him a bunch of time by actually
exposing a little bit more information
about what's actually going on under the
hood and on the right hand side this
gentleman has actually thinks he found a
bug in a cloud database and he's just
gonna write some software to work around
that bug but in a better model couldn't
he actually verify that this is the case
and then let's actually try to get this
bug fixed instead of writing a software
workaround so this is kind of what you
want to go for you want something that's
a little bit more transparent you can
actually see what's going on and it
saves everybody a whole bunch of time so
the crunchy data operator we just looked
at is one of a number on operator hub do
and this is a community listing of
operators we're adding new operators
every single day and so some of the new
ones that just came in the elasticsearch
operator from elastic a bunch of the
come framework components of Sto the
service mesh or in there so take a look
there's a whole bunch more out there
really really great resource and then if
this this vision of a true hybrid cloud
this cloud like experience coming to
your kubernetes cluster resonates with
you or your customers Red Hat wants to
help you bring these products to market
we have a new operator certification
program and this is really important
because Red Hat is truly neutral in this
you know there's some open source
licensing shenanigans going on right now
and you know you need to pick a partner
that's truly neutral and wants to bring
this to market with you so that interest
you please get in touch we would love to
have you now once you're an admin and
you've got these operators installed on
your cluster
you get full control over what's going
on so here you can introspect the
versions of the operators that we have
running see what's namespaces those
capabilities are exposed into so you
really have really nice visibility of
what's going on so you can run your
production infrastructure but the most
important thing is this is all self
service for your engineers these are the
folks that are using your cluster
they're running the applications and so
they have GUI access you can deploy
these via the command line and you know
you're just eating into your cluster
quota you don't have to call anybody to
change an environment variable and
staging and promote that to production
of great things and it's really really
powerful for speeding up your team's so
I want to invite you to check out
operator hub do and take a look at some
of these great operators but more
importantly if you want to build an
operator yourself take a look at our
getting started guide for our sdk it's
really really quick and easy to get
started and I want to encourage you not
just to focus on the partners that you
saw on stage today but building
operators for your internal applications
everybody's got really complex state
going on you need to share that between
groups even inside of your company so an
SDK is a really great way to get started
with an operator to do that and then if
you choose to do this and you want to
you know run some common scenarios by
other folks solve some problems
collaboratively we've got an operator
sig that meets monthly and we love to
have you join that community as well so
that's a quick update on the operator
ecosystem thank you so much
[Applause]
